The shadow moves into the torch light.[/p] [p]``Look out, Caric,'' Laurus cries, ``It's a black pudding!''[/p] [p]The pudding oozes down the corridor. It's large, blobby body eats away everything in its path. It will soon reach you.[/p] [p]``Oh my gosh!'' screams the halfling. ``What do we do now? Everybody knows there's no way to fight a pudding!''[/p] [p]``Well,'' you say, ``My sword hasn't failed me yet.''[/p]
p.next: If you choose to stay and face the pudding
If you decide to try the dimly lit corridor

p.text: [p]This corridor is smooth and well-lit. Gripping your sword and your mirror-bright shield firmly as you stride down the passageway, you come to an archway in front of you. The sound of heavy breathing comes from beyond. A cool breeze blows down a tunnel running uphill on your left.[/p] [p]Suddenly, mocking laughter rings out from the archway, and a deep voice says, ``Well done, fighter. Hello again, halfling. You surprise me, I had not thought to see you again.''[/p] [p]There is a long silence.[/p] [p]``Maybe we should turn back,'' says Laurus. ``That sounded like Kalman.''[/p] [p]``The treasure is probably very close,'' you say, ``I don't want to give up yet.''[/p]
p.next: If you choose to seek the treasure and possibly face Kalman, go down the tunnel
If you decide to avoid the wizard, go back up the corridor on the left

p.text: [p class="inlineImage" data-img="95"][/p] [p]You decide that if you are both careful and lucky, you might be able to kill the hill giant. An idea comes to you, and you quickly tell Laurus your plan.[/p] [p]You and the halfling begin to dig and scrape the earth from beneath the support beam with your swords. It is slow work, for the ground is hard and rocky, but you do not give up.[/p] [p]At last you make some progress. The beam moves, and the rock ceiling groans.[/p] [p]You push the beam with all your might, and the ceiling begins to collapse. You and Laurus duck back into the shelter of the corridor, and watch the ceiling crash into the room upon the giant.[/p] [p]The hill giant doesn't stand a chance. The debris buries it..[/p] [p]When the dust settles, you see that a path is clear over the rubble in the room and into the corridor beyond. As you pass over the pile of rubble, Laurus reaches down and pulls a sack from beneath a rock. He opens it, and you see six large emeralds inside.[/p] [p]``Jimminy!'' he says. ``My wife'll like one of those.''[/p] [p]He hands you three of the emeralds, and you put them in your pouch.[/p]

[p]You decide not to attack. Instead, you bow before the blink dogs.[/p] [p]They yip and yelp and seem to smile at you! Then, BLINK! They are gone! You are glad you did not fight them.[/p] [p]``Hey!'' exclaims Laurus. ``How did you get them to do that? I wish I'd known that trick when I was young. Dogs always seemed to think I was something good to eat!''[/p] [p]You do not enter their room. Instead, you continue down the corridor you were following. It turns to the left.[/p] [p]Suddenly, BLINK! The blink dogs appear in front of you with no warning.[/p] [p]``Arghh!'' cries Laurus, leaping behind you. ``They're coming to get me! Make them go away!''[/p] [p]But the blink dogs crowd about your legs, licking your hands and nipping at your heels. They follow you down the corridor, frisking about and occasionally blinking in and out. The halfling bravely controls his fear of them.[/p] [p]You pass a corridor on your right that reflects green light. The dogs avoid the corridor, but you do not. You walk down the corridor just far enough to see a room with a large stone pillar in the center of it.[/p] [p]There is a pool of green slime near the base of the pillar, and globs of the horrible stuff drip from the ceiling and archways in the room. You quickly decide to go back to the corridor where the dogs wait.[/p] [p]The dogs are glad to see you return, and they trot down the corridor ahead of you. You are following them when they stop and snarl at the corridor ahead. Bright white fangs threaten the unseen enemy. You are even happier now that you did not choose to fight the dogs. But what has alarmed them so?[/p] [p]You hear a strange clicking noise from around the corner.[/p] [p]Peering around the corner, you see two skeletons approaching. Both skeletons hold swords in their bony hands.[/p] [p]You draw back in horror[/p]
p.next: If you choose to fight the skeletons with the blink dogs
If you decide the skeletons are too frightening to face, run back to the slime-filled room and leave the blink dogs to their fate

p.text: [p]You decide the hobgoblin is too horrible to fight. You aren't sure you could defeat it.[/p] [p]You rush into the corridor with the strange green glow.[/p] [p]The hobgoblin stands at the entrance of the corridor and roars in fury, but does not follow. You wonder why.[/p] [p]Soon you come to the end of the corridor. Ahead of you the passage opens into a brightly lit room with running water and what appears to be a store of food.[/p] [p]On your left is an unlit corridor. The support beams look shaky and unsafe.[/p] [p]Now you know why the hobgoblin didn't follow you. Between you and the storeroom a large stone pillar rises to the ceiling. There is a large pool of green slime at the base of the pillar, and all the archways in the room drip great globs of the horrible stuff.[/p] [p]The green slime hisses and bubbles, dissolving everything it touches. ``What can we do?'' asks Laurus.[/p] [p]``We can't fight it,'' you say, ``It would dissolve our swords. I guess we only have two choices. We can try this dark corridor, or we can try to figure out a safe way past the slime.''[/p]
p.next: If you choose the dark corridor
If you choose to battle the green slime

p.text: [p class="inlineImage" data-img="100"][/p] [p]You doubt the corridor behind you holds anything less hideous than the gargoyle. Your heart racing wildly, you decide to take your chances with the gargoyle.[/p] [p]Slowly you edge around the corner of the wooden beam on the side of the doorway. Laurus, who has remained close by your side, stumbles over a rock and falls full length upon the ground with a large ``Whump!'' Your courage fails you and your feet refuse to move. You stand frozen with fear.[/p] [p]The gargoyle swivels its ugly head in your direction and gives a terrible shriek. Leaping down from its pedestal, it prances and dances like a demon, flapping it's wings and drawing ever closer and closer.[/p] [p]``Run Caric, run! Don't stop for me,'' cries the halfling.[/p] [p]But you cannot leave your friend. The gargoyle's eyes fix on you, still standing in front of the wooden beam.[/p] [p]The gargoyle is now only ten feet from you. It continues to prance about, showing exactly what it plans to do to you.[/p] [p]At last, bored with taunting, the gargoyle draws back, and lowers its head until the spiral horn points at your chest. It runs towards you.[/p] [p]Waiting until the last minute, you fall and lay at the base of the wooden beam.[/p] [p]The gargoyle charges over you and, unable to stop its rush, slams into the beam so hard it impales its horn deep in the wood! Try as it might, it cannot pull its horn out of the beam. Its screams echo through the room and down the corridor.[/p] [p]The beast's arms and legs kick and flail, battering you.[/p] [p]Quickly scrambling to your feet, you and Laurus race off into the corridor on the opposite side of the room.[/p]

[p]This tunnel leads downward for a time and levels out. Once again the tunnel divides, one passage to the left, the other to the right.[/p] [p]You hear and see nothing coming from the left corridor.[/p] [p]You feel a cool breeze coming from the right corridor.[/p] [p]``Confounded tunnels!'' Laurus says. ``They all look the same! I give up! You decide, Caric. Which way do you want to go?''[/p]
p.next: If you decide to go left
If you decide to go right

p.text: [p class="inlineImage" data-img="103"][/p] [p]As you jump into the room, the blink dogs snarl and whine. Their barks must be a language of some sort, for they seem to talk to each other. They blink in and out of sight too rapidly to follow.[/p] [p]``Blasted dogs,'' says Laurus, ``I hate them.''[/p] [p]You slash out at a dog, but the animal blinks away and you strike only air. Again and again this happens. The yelping dogs sound suspiciously like they are laughing at you.[/p] [p]You swing your sword wildly at the lead dog. You are certain it will strike! At the last moment, though, the dog and all of the pups disappear![/p] [p]You wait, but they do not return. It feels strange to have been defeated by a pack of dogs.[/p] [p]Anxious to leave the spot of your embarrassment, you mutter, ``Let's get out of here.''[/p] [p]The halfling struggles to keep up with you as you stride down the corridor.[/p] [p]Ahead of you, a passage opens to the right, and, further down, another opens to the left. Both are well-lit, and when you look down the corridor on the right, you notice a strange green glow.[/p] [p]A hobgoblin comes into view from the left hand corridor. Its yellow eyes stare menacingly at you. The hobgoblin grins and stalks toward you.[/p] [p]``Let's get out of here,'' cries Laurus, ``That's the ugliest monster I've ever seen.''[/p] [p]``But then we'll have to run down the corridor with the green glow,'' you say. ``I'm not sure I like that idea.''[/p]
p.next: If you choose to stand and face the hobgoblin
If you choose to avoid the hobgoblin

p.text: [p]This corridor clearly leads upwards. The corridor ends at a giant boulder which blocks further travel. While carefully examining its surface, you discover a cleverly hidden latch carved into the stone. You press the latch and the boulder swings aside. All is darkness beyond. Carefully, you step forward. Evil laughter pours forth from some invisible source, and the boulder swings shut behind you.[/p] [p]``Caric!'' exclaims Laurus. ``We're outside!''[/p] [p]``Well,'' you say, slightly disappointed you did not get to fight the wizard, ``We may not have found all the treasure in the world, but I'd say we had a profitable adventure.''[/p] [p]``Yes,'' Laurus says, ``I never thought I'd be rich!''[/p] [p]``We're not exactly rich,'' you answer, ``But we can live comfortably for awhile. I think I'll use the rest of my share to organize an expedition to come back and drive Kalman from the mountain. Will you join me, Laurus?''[/p] [p]Laurus nods, ``There's only one thing I like more than food,'' he says, ``and that's treasure.''[/p] [p]You laugh and, putting your arm around Laurus, start down the mountain toward home.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="106"][/p] [p]``Listen,'' you say, ``we can handle it. I know we can. Why does everyone thing it's so terrible? It doesn't look very dangerous. How can anything that looks like a pudding kill a big, strong person dressed in armor?''[/p] [p]``I don't know, Caric,'' he says. ``But the stuff is so oozy, so slimy. It makes me nervous. Are you sure you want to do this?''[/p] [p]``Stand back,'' you answer. ``I thought you were getting braver. I'll handle this!''[/p] [p]You take your sword and begin hacking away at the pudding. You soon discover you should have listened to Laurus' warnings. The pudding has divided and now wriggles across the floor toward you in hundreds of small pieces.[/p] [p]Your sword is beginning to disintegrate. The awful ooze has encircled and trapped you.[/p] [p]You snatch a torch from the wall and hold it against the right edge of the ooze. It works! The smell of scorched milk rises from the bubbling mass, and it retreats slightly.[/p] [p]``Caric, look out!'' cries the halfling from the far edge of the corridor. You do not even spare him a glance, you are too busy burning away the goo.[/p] [p]You are so pleased with your success, you fail to notice the advance of the pudding on your left side. Even now it creeps across your foot and dissolves the leather of your boot.[/p] [p]You cry out in pain and back away. You are trapped by the relentlessly moving pudding. You slip and fall to the floor. Your last thought is 'those who foolishly seek danger find it.'[/p] [p]The horrified halfling watches from the safety of his corner, unable to help you in any way. He leaves the same way he entered.[/p] [p]``Poor Caric was the best friend I've ever had. He taught me to recognize my own value. What greater gift can there be from a friend? When I return home I shall organize a party. We shall enter the dungeon, rid the place of monsters, and drive Kalman away for good.''[/p] [p]``I shall build a statue in honor of my friend Caric. From this day forward, I shall be known as Laurus the Brave.''[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="108"][/p] [p]``Well,'' you say, shaking yourself, ``I guess this is what we came for. If we've come this far, we might as well see it through.''[/p] [p]With great caution, the two of you approach a bend in the passage and slowly peek around the corner.[/p] [p]A large cavern lies before you. Gold coins lie in heaps on the sandy floor. Gems sparkle every color of the rainbow over the entire floor. Heavy silver bricks are stacked in great mounds near the walls. Your breath is taken away by the vast treasure, far more treasure than any person could ever use in a lifetime![/p] [p]``My apologies, Laurus!'' you say. ``I thought you were exaggerating, but you were not. It does seem that all the world's treasure is here!''[/p] [p]At last reason returns to both of you.[/p] [p]You were so dazzled by the treasure, you failed to notice some other details of the cavern.[/p] [p]Two inch iron bars protect the treasure. They would be impossible to break. The only opening in the barrier is a small iron door with an unusual keyhole, shaped like a cross with a diamond on each end.[/p] [p]``Caric, look at all the statues. Don't they look odd?''[/p] [p]You notice a number of statues standing around the iron bars. Some of them actually clutch the bars in their hands. The statues are remarkably lifelike. They are humans, halflings, elves, and even a dwarf.[/p] [p]Both of you move closer, marveling at the workmanship of the statues. They are very life-like.[/p] [p]``You're right Laurus, look at their expressions.''[/p] [p]More than half wear expressions of horror on their faces. Many have raised hands, as though protecting themselves from danger. What kind of sculptor could have created such strange figures?[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="109"][/p] [p]Suddenly, a terrible thought enters your mind![/p] [p]``Laurus,'' you ask, ``do you think these statues were not sculpted? Maybe they were living beings who were turned to stone.''[/p] [p]``Remember the words written in the entrance? 'Watch the water that is not water, and beware the basilisk!' I think we've stumbled into the basilisk's lair!''[/p] [p]The fate of the statues, who were once living beings, is now clear. Anyone unfortunate enough to look into the eyes of a basilisk instantly turns to stone. There is no escape.[/p] [p]``What can we do to protect ourselves?'' asks the halfling, wildly. ``I don't want to be a statue!''[/p] [p]Quickly, you think of all you know about the dreadful creatures. A basilisk is a reptilian monster nearly ten feet long. The only way to protect yourself from turning to stone is to reflect the basilisk's gaze back into its own eyes, so it will be turned to stone![/p] [p]Suddenly, the heavy breathing becomes louder.[/p] [p]Oh no, it's the basilisk! You don't dare turn around.[/p] [p]``Laurus,'' you whisper, ``don't turn around. Whatever you do, do not turn around!''[/p] [p]You stand in place, eyes tightly closed, trying to think of your next move.[/p] [p]Evil laughter bursts forth and a voice hisses, ``Do you know our secret, fighter? Come, turn around and meet my pet. Not many come this far, and none leave, except, of course, your small friend. It seems I made a mistake, but who expects worms to grow backbones? This dungeon is a profitable and pleasant place for me, and I do not intend to let you spoil my fun. Come, turn around!''[/p] [p]A wild plan forms in your mind. You don't know if it will work, but it's worth a try. Anything is better than becoming the newest statue in the wizard's collection![/p] [p]Quickly, you whisper your plan to Laurus. Slowly, the two of you lower your heads and raise your shields at the same time. The highly polished surfaces cover your faces.[/p] [p]Perhaps you can reflect the horrible creature's gaze back into its own eyes, and turn it to stone.[/p] [p]You spin around to face the basilisk. You hear it hiss as it approaches, and feel its hot breath on your legs. Abruptly, there is a crunching, crackling, splintering sound, and then there is only silence.[/p] [p]``Kalman,'' you call out, ``We would go in peace.'' There is no answer![/p] [p]``Caric!'' the halfling says, ``The breathing has stopped.''[/p] [p]You peer out from behind your shield. At first you see only sand. Then you see a scaly hide. But the hide is made of stone! The basilisk lies on its side in the sand, frozen forever in stone![/p] [p]``It worked, Laurus! Our plan worked!''[/p] [p]``But where is Kalman?'' asks Laurus.[/p] [p]``Maybe he fled,'' you respond.[/p]
p.next: If you want to search the room
Perhaps Kalman fled when you turned his basilisk to stone so you may try to open the lock guarding the treasure

p.text: [p]As you touch the lock, an ear-splitting screech fills the room. Turning toward the sound, you barely have time to duck the bolts of lightning Kalman releases from his fingertips.[/p] [p]``Turn my pet to stone, will you?'' the evil wizard screeches.[/p] [p]Another lightning bolt sizzles through the air.[/p] [p]You jump to the ground to avoid the deadly bolt, but Laurus surprises you by running under the bolt and hitting Kalman square in the knees.[/p] [p]The surprised wizard falls.[/p] [p]``Come quick,'' Laurus gasps, ``I can't hold him long. He's so much bigger than I.''[/p] [p]You jump to your feet, and, tugging at your cloak's clasp, run to help the halfling. You barely have time to drag Laurus from the struggle before the wizard raises his hand to cast another spell. You fling your cloak over the wizard's head and, pulling Laurus along, run down the corridor out of the treasure room.[/p] [p]As you clear the bend, Kalman screams ``Centipedes! I'll turn you both into centipedes!''[/p] [p]You turn left as soon as you clear his chambers. You run breathlessly up this corridor for ten minutes.[/p] [p]Neither you or the halfling says anything until you reach the end. A boulder blocks the way. You push, but it does not budge.[/p] [p]``Hurry, Caric!'' Laurus urges, ``He's coming.''[/p] [p]You grasp at the boulder, trying to get a better grip, and you find a handle, which you pull. The boulder swings away from the corridor. It was a secret door! You rush out of the dungeon into crisp, cool night air.[/p] [p]You do not stop running until you rest deep in the forest.[/p] [p]``I think we'll be safe here,'' you gasp.[/p] [p]``Well, Laurus,'' you say, disappointed you did not get Kalman's treasure, ``Let's go home.'' But the halfling is busy fishing something out of his pocket. When his hand reappears, he holds two diamonds, each as large as a walnut.[/p] [p]``I know this isn't much,'' he grins, ``But I tried.''[/p] [p]``Maybe Kalman got the best of us this time,'' you chuckle, ``But with those diamonds, we can buy the equipment we need and come back to chase him from his evil lair.''[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="115"][/p] [p]Kalman steps into your sight. ``Here I am, worms,'' he says. ``My little joke has gone on too long. What shall I do with you? Maybe I'll turn you into slugs. Then I can step on you whenever I please.''[/p] [p]``How about a fair fight, Kalman?'' you ask.[/p] [p]``Don't be silly, fighter,'' he answers. ``I didn't study all those years to fight fair. I much prefer fighting like a magic-user.'' He roars with laughter and shoots four bursts of silver-white light from his fingers. You and the halfling jump for cover.[/p] [p]``Hiding won't save you, my little slugs,'' he hisses.[/p] [p]You hear sizzling noises, then a blinding pain surges through your elbow. You have time to do no more than gasp with pain before eight more bursts arc toward you.[/p] [p]Rolling in terror, you try to dodge, but they follow you and burn into your body. You lay gasping on the ground, dimly aware of Laurus whimpering in the background.[/p] [p]Kalman laughs. ``Do you see what I mean? Now, stop your silly whining, and come here, heroes,'' he sneers, ``I want to change you into worms.''[/p] [p]Kalman beckons you with a skinny finger. You find your body crawling to him, despite your mind's desire to escape his foul lair.[/p] [p]At last you lie stretched out on the sand in front of Kalman. Laurus moans softly as he crawls to your side.[/p] [p]``My sweet pet,'' Kalman croons to his stone basilisk, ``I shall avenge you. Shall I turn them into slugs or little black spiders? Both squish nicely when you step on them.''[/p] [p]Your skin crawls. You do not want to be turned into any kind of bug. If only you could draw your weapon![/p] [p]Suddenly the halfling's furious voice screams ``Noooo!!! You aren't going to turn me into a bug. I hate bugs!''[/p] [p]You lift your head in amazement as Laurus flings himself at the wizard.[/p] [p]``I don't want to be a bug!'' screams the halfling, locking his arms around Kalman's knees and struggling to topple the evil wizard.[/p] [p]Kalman's amusement turns to anger. He finds it difficult to pull the halfling away.[/p] [p]Kalman raises his hands and points his fingertips at the halfling.[/p] [p]Laurus screams, ``No! I don't want to be hurt either!''[/p] [p]He gives a great jerk that throws Kalman off balance. For a moment the halfling and the wizard sway back and forth. Then the two topple to the ground. Ignoring your pain, you force yourself to your knees and crawl to the struggling wizard and halfling.[/p] [p]``Get off me, you miserable halfling! I'll turn you into a centipede.'' screams the wizard, attempting to free himself.[/p] [p]``I hate bugs, I hate bugs!'' screams the halfling.[/p] [p]Finally, Kalman wrenches one leg free and kicks at the halfling.[/p] [p]You realize this is your only chance. If you are to live, you must do something now.[/p] [p]Gathering all your strength, you fling yourself on top of the struggling wizard and grab both his wrists to prevent him from throwing any more spells.[/p] [p]Kalman roars in fury. His evil face is only inches away from your own. His lips curl back in a dog-like snarl.[/p] [p]``You cannot win, fighter,'' he hisses, ``Even with this stupid halfling holding my leg, I am more than a match for you. When you creep through black tunnels on your belly, waving your antennae in the air, you will wish you had never touched me.''[/p] [p]You are about to reply when the wizard shoves you mightily. Both of you tumble, locked in each other's grip.[/p] [p]Laurus clings as hard as he can to Kalman's legs.[/p] [p]``Do something, Caric!'' he cries, ``Do something!''[/p] [p]``Do what?'' you gasp, ``I don't want to be turned into a bug any more than you!''[/p] [p]Try as you may, you cannot do more than just hold on to Kalman. You are weakening fast. The constant bashing causes your injuries to throb and ache.[/p] [p]Risking the chance Kalman will free himself, you reach down and draw your sword. Kalman dashes you against the cavern wall and your aching fingers drop the weapon. Kalman yells triumphantly and rolls away. He seizes your sword and flings it across the room.[/p]

[p]Carefully picking your way through the debris, you and the halfling gladly leave the hill giant behind you and hurry on your way.[/p] [p]The path is straight and appears free from danger. Soon the corridor ends and two new passages open, one to your left, another to your right. You hear nothing from either corridor.[/p]
p.next: If you choose to go left
If you choose to go right

p.text: [p class="inlineImage" data-img="120"][/p] [p]Rolling away from Kalman, you strike the treasure room bars. Realizing you are near the end of your strength, Kalman jumps on top of you.[/p] [p]``Now!'' he hisses, pointing a bony finger at your face. Just as you think the end is near, Kalman screeches terribly and falls aside.[/p] [p]``You bit me,'' the wizard screams, ``Let go! Let go!''[/p] [p]Laurus has wrapped himself around Kalman's legs, his teeth clamped on the evil wizard's leg.[/p] [p]You scramble for your sword, but it lies across the room. Your hand fumbles about, searching for anything that can serve as a weapon. Your fingers close upon coins, jewels, a chalice – useless, all useless.[/p] [p]Suddenly your fingers encounter a slender, heavy metal rod.[/p] [p]The rod grows warm as soon as you touch it. As you bring it forward, you see that the rod glows pale green. Kalman's eyes open wide and he grows pale. Horror spreads over his face. He cringes, hands held before him, trying to escape the rod. His mouth moves, but no words come out.[/p] [p]You strike Kalman with the rod.[/p] [p]Before your disbelieving eyes, the wizard's body grows stiff, then breaks into dozens of splinters. As you stare at the shattered wizard, you hear hissing. A stinking black cloud explodes from the broken body.[/p] [p]You and Laurus edge as far away from the cloud as possible. What will this cloud reveal?[/p] [p]The stinking cloud billows and rolls, hiding all that lies beneath it.[/p] [p]Laurus shivers and clings to you. His teeth chatter with fear.[/p] [p]A horrible ear-splitting, heart-stopping screech assaults your ears and an inhuman head pokes out of the cloud. It glares at you.[/p] [p]It is the ugliest head you have ever seen. It looks like a chicken, but it has no feathers. The eyes are large and lidless. A large curved beak snaps open and shut. The head turns back and forth, the bright red eyes studying the detail of the room.[/p] [p]You start to move slowly toward your sword. As soon as you move, the creature squawks loudly and rises above the cloud on two bat-like wings. It hovers in the middle of the room, too frightening to look upon.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="121"][/p] [p]It appears to be a cross between a bird and a snake. A large bird-like body covered with scales hangs suspended between the two large bat-like wings. Dirty white feathery down covers its shoulders and there are razor-sharp talons on each of its four legs. The creature beats its wings upon the air, uncertainly at first, then stronger at every flap.[/p] [p]``Caric,'' the halfling squeaks, ``We better do something or that chicken-thing is going to eat us.''[/p] [p]You edge toward your sword.[/p] [p]Screeching wildly, the creature dives at you. You slash out with the rod, which no longer glows, and strike it on one white wing. As it swoops by, the sharp talons rip at your clothing.[/p] [p]The creature swoops and dives in bat-like bursts of speed. You grow dizzy following its flight.[/p] [p]Finally the creature dives straight for you, driving its clawed foot deep into your shoulder. It slashes once, then twice, and circles the room. Then, its great wings beating, it flies down the black corridor.[/p] [p]You collapse to the ground, bleeding.[/p] [p]Laurus rushes to your side and gently cradles your head. Ripping cloth from his shirt, he presses it against your wound. He feels your shoulder gently to see what damage the creature did.[/p] [p]``You are lucky Caric, it didn't get your face, but you'll have an interesting scar, that's for sure. Do you think you can get up? That screechy chicken might come back and I don't want to be here.''[/p] [p]Although your head spins and your body aches, you struggle to your feet. As you rise, the metal rod tumbles to the ground.[/p] [p]``Thank heaven for that magical stick,'' says Laurus.[/p] [p]``We would be crawling along some corridor right now, if not for that wand,'' you say.[/p] [p]``I don't know what it was, but I'm sure glad we found it. I don't think we could have defeated Kalman without it.''[/p] [p]``Kalman!'' shouts the halfling, ``Where is he? Where's he gone to?''[/p] [p]Laurus whirls wildly about, searching for the wizard.[/p] [p]``He's gone, Laurus,'' you say, holding his shoulders, ``You'll find whatever remains of Kalman when you find that creature.''[/p] [p]``I don't think I want to find either one,'' says the halfling. ``What was that chicken-thing, anyway?''[/p] [p]``I don't know,'' you answer, ``But if we're lucky, it's the only one of its kind. We must hope it finds our world an unfriendly place and dies. I don't want to think of what might happen if it lives. Only Kalman knew for certain.''[/p] [p]``Does this mean we've won?'' asks Laurus. ``Are we rich now?''[/p] [p]You turn and face the locked door to the treasure room.[/p]

[p]You look sadly at the treasure room door. You could never break that door down, even with your best effort.[/p] [p]``No, Laurus, we're not rich. We might as well not have come at all.''[/p] [p]``What do you mean, Caric?'' the halfling asks. ``There's all the treasure in the world sitting right there.''[/p] [p]``Yes,'' you answer sadly, ``that is almost all the treasure in the world. But it won't do us any good. I can't break that door down.''[/p] [p]Laurus looks at you strangely. Then, taking a piece of stiff wire from his pocket, he walks over to the treasure room door. He bends the wire in two places, inserts it into the lock, twists, and pop! The door swings open.[/p] [p]``Laurus!'' you gasp. ``How'd you do that?''[/p] [p]``It was nothing,'' Laurus responds proudly. ``I've been picking locks since I was knee-high to a grasshopper. Now we've got all the treasure in the world.''[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="126"][/p] [p]You open your leather pouch and pull forth the key you snatched from the water weird's room. With trembling fingers you fit the key to the lock and turn. The lock clicks and the door opens. The treasure is yours![/p] [p]``Whoosee,'' yells Laurus, leaping past you and tumbling in the treasure. ``Wait till me missus sees some of this. She'll think once or twice before she yells at me again!''[/p] [p]Sitting upon a pile of gold, he rains a shower of gems down upon himself.[/p] [p]You gaze about the treasure room, and say, ``You realize all this treasure was stolen. We can never hope to find the rightful owners, but we could donate part of it to the poor of your village. There would still be untold riches for us to share.''[/p] [p]Laurus stuffs his pockets with gold, then sits back on an open chest. ``What are you going to do with your share?'' he asks.[/p] [p]``I think I shall claim this mountain for my own, and dedicate myself to stamping out evil.''[/p] [p]``And I shall build a school for the training of fighters,'' you continue. ``Fighters who wish to be good, not evil. And you Laurus the Brave, will you be my right hand man?''[/p] [p]The halfling rises and walks to your side. His small face looks up into yours and he smiles. He extends his hand. ``I'm your man,'' he says.[/p] [p]You clasp his hand tightly and leave the treasure room. ``We'll come back for the rest later,'' you say.[/p] [p]You edge past the basilisk and return to the breezy corridor you noticed just before you entered Kalman's treasure room. You find a narrow, spiraling staircase.[/p] [p]The staircase curves upwards for a long time. At last, you find yourself standing before a huge boulder that blocks any further progress. Searching its surface carefully, you notice a cleverly hidden latch. You pull it and the boulder swings aside. Sunlight streams in. You are outdoors! You are alive and you have found treasure enough to last several lifetimes! Suddenly, the boulder swings shut behind you.[/p] [p]You turn around and see nothing but the smooth face of the mountain. But you are not dismayed. You know that when you both return you will find the entrance and enter the dungeon again, this time as the owners![/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]
